questions.text: Calculate the ECF volume in a volunteer in whom 10 gm of mannitol was injected in venous blood. At equilibrium urinary excretion of mannitol was found to be 10% and the plasma concentration of mannitol was 65 mg/100 ml? In a volunteer, 10 grams of mannitol was injected into the venous blood. At equilibrium, the urinary excretion of mannitol was found to be 10% and the plasma concentration of mannitol was measured at 65 mg/100 ml. Calculate the extracellular fluid (ECF) volume based on this information. ( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 14L

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The extracellular fluid (ECF) volume can be calculated by using the dilution principle, taking into account the amount of marker substance injected, the amount excreted, and the plasma concentration of the marker.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary identification made by a CBNAAT or GeneXpert? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT), also known as GeneXpert, is a molecular diagnostic test used for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and its resistance to the anti-tubercular drug rifampicin.
  • • The key points are:
  • • The key points are:
  • • CBNAAT or GeneXpert is a molecular method based on real-time PCR that can detect the presence of MTB. (Detection limit à about 131 bacilli/mL of specimen) In addition to detecting MTB, it can also detect resistance to the drug rifampicin by identifying mutations in the rpoB gene, which is associated with rifampicin resistance CBNAAT/GeneXpert primarily identifies the presence of MTB and rifampicin resistance.
  • • CBNAAT or GeneXpert is a molecular method based on real-time PCR that can detect the presence of MTB. (Detection limit à about 131 bacilli/mL of specimen)
  • • In addition to detecting MTB, it can also detect resistance to the drug rifampicin by identifying mutations in the rpoB gene, which is associated with rifampicin resistance
  • • CBNAAT/GeneXpert primarily identifies the presence of MTB and rifampicin resistance.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other
  • • Options:
  • • Option A. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: While CBNAAT can detect the presence of MTB, it also provides information on rifampicin resistance, making this option incomplete.
  • • Option A. Mycobacterium tuberculosis:
  • • Option C. MTB + Rifampicin resistance + Isoniazid resistance: CBNAAT does not directly detect resistance to isoniazid, another first-line anti-tubercular drug.
  • • Option C. MTB + Rifampicin resistance + Isoniazid resistance:
  • • Option D. MTB + Rifampicin resistance + Ethambutol resistance: CBNAAT does not detect resistance to ethambutol, another first-line anti-tubercular drug.
  • • Option D. MTB + Rifampicin resistance + Ethambutol resistance:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT or GeneXpert) is a molecular diagnostic tool that primarily identifies the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and its resistance to the anti-tubercular drug rifampicin by detecting mutations in the rpoB gene.

questions.text: Identify the sinus marked in the given image: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Maxillary sinus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ethmoid Sinus : Located between the nose and the eyes, within the ethmoid bone. It is a collection of small air cells. Frontal Sinus : Located above the eyes, in the frontal bone. These are typically well above the maxillary sinuses. Sphenoid Sinus : Located deeper and more centrally behind the nasal cavity, in the sphenoid bone. Maxillary Sinus: Located beneath the orbits, on either side of the nose.
  • ➤ Ethmoid Sinus : Located between the nose and the eyes, within the ethmoid bone. It is a collection of small air cells.
  • ➤ Ethmoid Sinus
  • ➤ Frontal Sinus : Located above the eyes, in the frontal bone. These are typically well above the maxillary sinuses.
  • ➤ Frontal Sinus
  • ➤ Sphenoid Sinus : Located deeper and more centrally behind the nasal cavity, in the sphenoid bone.
  • ➤ Sphenoid Sinus
  • ➤ Maxillary Sinus: Located beneath the orbits, on either side of the nose.
  • ➤ Maxillary Sinus:

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition exhibited by A. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) Competitive inhibition

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Competitive inhibition is identified by an increased Km and unchanged Vmax, with intersecting lines on the y-axis of the Lineweaver-Burk plot

questions.text: At the Urban Primary Health Centre (U-PHC), you are in charge of managing hypertension clinic services. You have 50 patients transferred from another healthcare unit for hypertension management; 40 of these patients are prescribed amlodipine (5mg, daily) and 10 are on lisinopril (10mg, daily) due to contraindications with amlodipine. Considering the need for continuous treatment and potential increases in patient numbers, calculate the number of tablets needed for the next month and determine the appropriate reorder factor. (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 3000, rf=2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Reorder Factor (rf): A reorder factor of 2 is commonly used for monthly resupply scenarios to account for unexpected increases in patient count or dosage adjustments, ensuring no interruption in patient care.
  • ➤ Reorder Factor (rf): A reorder factor of 2 is commonly used for monthly resupply scenarios to account for unexpected increases in patient count or dosage adjustments, ensuring no interruption in patient care.
  • ➤ Reorder Factor (rf):

questions.text: Phototherapy converts bilirubin to? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lumirubin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phototherapy converts bilirubin into lumirubin, a water-soluble isomer that can be excreted by the kidneys, making it an effective treatment for neonatal jaundice.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presented with cough, fatigability, and weight loss. He was diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) on bronchoscopy. The resected specimen had a hilar lymph node that was 1cm in size and showed a black pigment. What is the black pigment likely to be? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anthracotic pigment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anthracotic pigment, resulting from the deposition of carbon particles, is the most likely cause of the black pigment observed in the hilar lymph node of a patient with squamous cell carcinoma. This is common in individuals exposed to high levels of environmental pollution or occupational hazards involving carbon particles.

questions.text: A patient has adult respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following is the action of IL-8 in the pathogenesis in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Neutrophil activation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ IL-8 is a key mediator in ARDS that promotes neutrophil activation, which plays a major role in the amplification of inflammation and lung injury in the disease process.

questions.text: Match the Dermatological disorders in Column A with their respective investigations in Column B: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a, 4-d

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Correct matches:
  • • Correct matches:
  • • 1. Tinea : Tinea infections, also known as dermatophytosis, are fungal infections of the skin, hair, or nails. The diagnosis is commonly made by performing a potassium hydroxide (KOH) mount of skin scrapings, which reveals fungal hyphae under a microscope.
  • • 1. Tinea
  • • 2. Lepromatous leprosy : This form of leprosy is diagnosed using a slit skin smear, where a sample from the skin lesion is stained and examined for the presence of acid-fast bacilli (Mycobacterium leprae).
  • • 2. Lepromatous leprosy
  • • 3. Lupus vulgaris : Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis. The diagnosis often involves a biopsy of the lesion, which shows granulomatous inflammation with caseation necrosis and the presence of acid-fast bacilli.
  • • 3. Lupus vulgaris
  • • 4. Allergic dermatitis : Allergic contact dermatitis is diagnosed using a patch test, where suspected allergens are applied to the skin under occlusive patches to observe for a delayed hypersensitivity reaction.
  • • 4. Allergic dermatitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tinea is diagnosed with a KOH mount, lepromatous leprosy with a slit skin smear, lupus vulgaris with a biopsy, and allergic dermatitis with a patch test.

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of asthma and sinusitis. On looking into his medical records, you notice this has been attributed to Samter's triad. Which drug should be avoided in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Aspirin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients diagnosed with Samter's triad, it is crucial to avoid aspirin and other NSAIDs that inhibit COX-1, as these can trigger severe respiratory and nasal symptoms. Effective management involves identifying safe medications for pain and inflammation and regularly monitoring the respiratory and nasal health of the patient.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 193, 194
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 193, 194

questions.text: Identify the marked chamber? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Left atrium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The radiological image shows a transverse section of the heart.
  • • In a CT scan taken with the patient lying supine, the right atrium and right ventricle will be seen on the front side, while the left atrium and left ventricle will be at the back. The base (posterior surface) of the heart is mainly formed by the left atrium (two-thirds) and the right atrium (one-third).
  • • In the image, the vertebra is at the back, and the aorta is on the left side in front of the vertebra. The esophagus is closely related to the base of the heart, particularly the left atrium. The chamber marked in the question is the one just in front of the esophagus is the left atrium.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Right atrium: The right atrium is towards the right side and forms the right border of the heart in this view.
  • • Option A. Right atrium:
  • • Option C. Right ventricle: The right ventricle lies on the front side along with the right atrium. It forms the sternocostal surface of the heart. The marked chamber is at the back, so it cannot be the right ventricle.
  • • Option C. Right ventricle:
  • • Option D. Left ventricle : The left ventricle lies next to the left atrium at the back in this transverse section. However, the marked chamber is the one closest to the esophagus, which is the left atrium, not the left ventricle.
  • • Option D. Left ventricle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a transverse CT section of the heart, the right atrium and ventricle are seen anteriorly, while the left atrium and ventricle are seen posteriorly.

questions.text: Which of the following option is a common size of a Foley catheter used in female patients and patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 14 Fr

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ FOLEY’S CATHETER
  • ➤ FOLEY’S CATHETER
  • ➤ The size in French (12F, 14F, 16F etc.) represents the outer diameter. 1 F = 1/3 rd mm.
  • ➤ The size in French (12F, 14F, 16F etc.) represents the outer diameter. 1 F = 1/3 rd mm.

questions.text: A female patient presents to the clinic with a painful lump in her breast that has been increasing in size over the past few days. After examination, the doctor diagnoses her with a breast abscess and prescribes antibiotics to help clear the infection. The doctor attempts to aspirate the abscess using a needle and syringe, but no fluid is obtained. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: D
options.text: Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected

questions.correct_answer: C. A second attempt at aspiration
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. A second attempt at aspiration

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • If the first attempt at aspiration fails to obtain fluid, the next logical step is to attempt aspiration again, potentially with ultrasound guidance. Ultrasound guidance can enhance the accuracy of the procedure by allowing direct visualization of the abscess, ensuring that the needle is correctly positioned to access the abscess cavity. This method is less invasive than incision and drainage (I&D), making it a preferred option if it can effectively manage the abscess.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Incision and Drainage: Incision and drainage is generally considered if aspiration fails repeatedly or if the abscess is too large. While effective, it is not typically the immediate next step after a single failed aspiration attempt. It is more invasive than aspiration and usually reserved for cases where less invasive methods are unsuccessful.
  • • Option A. Incision and Drainage:
  • • Option B. Continue antibiotics only: Antibiotics are crucial in managing breast abscesses by treating the underlying infection. However, they alone might not suffice for large or dense abscesses. The pus trapped within the abscess often needs to be physically removed to expedite healing and provide symptom relief. Continuing antibiotics without addressing the abscess can lead to prolonged infection and discomfort.
  • • Option B. Continue antibiotics only:
  • • Option D. Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected: This option is not recommended. The failure to collect aspirate does not imply the absence of infection. The antibiotics were prescribed based on the clinical diagnosis of a breast abscess, and stopping them prematurely could allow the infection to worsen. Continuation of antibiotics is important until the course is complete or unless indicated otherwise by a physician.
  • • Option D. Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ If the initial aspiration attempt for a breast abscess fails, the next step should be to attempt aspiration again, preferably under ultrasound guidance, before considering more invasive procedures like incision and drainage. This approach ensures accurate access to the abscess and minimizes invasiveness.

questions.text: Which of the following are vitamin K dependent factors requiring gamma carboxylation? ( NEETPG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2, 7, 9, 10

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin K dependent factors are procoagulants (factors 2,7,9,10) and anticoagulants (protein C and S). They require gamma carboxylation for their activity.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented to OPD with complaint of greenish-frothy vaginal discharge for 1 month. Examination revealed finding as shown in image. On saline microscopy, motile organisms are noticed. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE jan 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Trichomoniasis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given clinical scenario and image showing strawberry cervix, is suggestive of Trichomoniasis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Bacterial Vaginosis
  • • Option B. Bacterial Vaginosis
  • • Discharge: White, thin, homogenous with a foul odor. Diagnosis: Amsel Criteria - clue cells on wet mount, whiff test positive, pH > 4.5, homogenous discharge. Symptoms: Usually no erythema or significant irritation.
  • • Discharge: White, thin, homogenous with a foul odor.
  • • Diagnosis: Amsel Criteria - clue cells on wet mount, whiff test positive, pH > 4.5, homogenous discharge.
  • • Symptoms: Usually no erythema or significant irritation.
  • • Option C. Chlamydial Cervicitis
  • • Option C. Chlamydial Cervicitis
  • • Typically associated with mucopurulent cervical discharge and may not present with frothy discharge or a strawberry cervix. Diagnosis: Nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT) are used to detect Chlamydia trachomatis.
  • • Typically associated with mucopurulent cervical discharge and may not present with frothy discharge or a strawberry cervix.
  • • Diagnosis: Nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT) are used to detect Chlamydia trachomatis.
  • • Option D. Candidiasis
  • • Option D. Candidiasis
  • • Discharge: Thick, curdy white with no odor. Diagnosis: KOH prep revealing pseudohyphae or spores, wet mount. Symptoms: Pruritis and dysuria with notable erythema.
  • • Discharge: Thick, curdy white with no odor.
  • • Diagnosis: KOH prep revealing pseudohyphae or spores, wet mount.
  • • Symptoms: Pruritis and dysuria with notable erythema.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trichomoniasis is characterized by greenish-frothy vaginal discharge, a strawberry cervix, and motile organisms on saline microscopy.
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Gynaecology 6 th edition page 166
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Gynaecology 6 th edition page 166

questions.text: A photographer who recently returned from Africa presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and hemorrhagic manifestations. He died despite treatment, and an autopsy revealed intranuclear Torres bodies in the liver. Which of the following vaccines could have prevented it? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 17D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The 17D vaccine could have prevented the yellow fever that led to the photographer's severe symptoms and death. This highlights the importance of appropriate vaccination before traveling to areas where yellow fever is endemic.

questions.text: As per Nutrition Guidelines of India, a 55 kg woman needs how many grams of proteins? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 45 grams

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • According to the nutrition guidelines of India, the protein requirement for adults is based on body weight.
  • • The recommended daily protein intake is 0.83 grams per kilogram of body weight. For an adult reference Indian woman weighing 55 kg, this translates to approximately 45 grams of protein per day (0.83 grams/kg/day x 55 kg = 45.65 grams/day, rounded to 45 grams).
  • • Additional Information –
  • • Additional Information –
  • • The recommended daily energy intake: [NEW GUIDELINES 2021-22]
  • • The recommended daily energy intake: [NEW GUIDELINES 2021-22]

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A 55 kg woman requires approximately 45 grams of protein per day according to the nutrition guidelines of India.

questions.text: A farmer had a thorn prick 3 weeks ago and presents with difficulty in opening jaw and muscle cramps. He is also having breathlessness. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tetanus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The diagnosis of tetanus should be considered in a patient with a history of a wound or injury followed by symptoms such as trismus, muscle cramps, and breathlessness, particularly if the onset of symptoms is delayed.

questions.text: A Cattle farmer with a scab lesion in the arm. Microscopic examination shows brick/box shaped gram-positive organism with squared ends and spores in the centre. Most likely organism which is responsible for his condition is? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bacillus anthracis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bacillus anthracis, with its brick/boxcar shape and central spores, is the causative agent of cutaneous anthrax, a zoonotic infection often seen in individuals handling livestock or animal products.

questions.text: In a patient with lipoprotein lipase deficiency, which of the following is increased following a fatty meal? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chylomicron

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Frederickson’s classification of hyperlipoproteinemia
  • ➤ Frederickson’s classification of hyperlipoproteinemia

questions.text: A patient is undergoing implant surgery for his upper limb. On giving general anesthesia he develops tachycardia, sudden raise in body temperature and rigidity of muscles. What drug is most likely to have caused this? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Halothane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Halothane, a volatile anesthetic, is a known trigger for malignant hyperthermia, characterized by hyperthermia, muscle rigidity, and tachycardia, especially in genetically predisposed individuals.

questions.text: Identify the operative procedure shown in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Resection and anastomosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In surgical procedures involving the bowel, when two bowel ends are being sutured together, the procedure is referred to as resection and anastomosis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presented with complaints of recurrent bleeding. On examination, following was seen on the CECT. All are false except: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

options.label: C
options.text: Bleeding is from the adjacent invading vessels

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tumor vessel lack contractility

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tumor vessels are known to lack contractility, which contributes to the risk of bleeding associated with tumors, as they cannot constrict effectively to stop blood flow when damaged.

questions.text: A young patient undergoing treatment for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) presents with symptoms of weight gain, cold intolerance, and lethargy. Laboratory investigations reveal high levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and low levels of T3 (triiodothyronine) and T4 (thyroxine). Which of the following drugs is likely responsible for these symptoms? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ethionamide.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ethionamide, a second-line drug used in the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB), can cause hypothyroidism, characterized by symptoms such as weight gain, cold intolerance, lethargy, elevated TSH, and low T3 and T4 levels.

questions.text: A 24-year-old presented with swelling in the wrist joint. Histopathological examination of the swelling revealed spindle cells with palisading of the nuclei and Verocay bodies. Which of the following is the most likely condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Schwannoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Schwannomas are characterized by spindle cells with palisading nuclei and Verocay bodies, forming well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses. These features, along with S-100 protein expression, distinguish schwannomas from other types of nerve sheath tumors and central nervous system tumors.

questions.text: A tumor of the uncinate process of the pancreas affects which of the following vessels? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Superior mesenteric artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The uncinate process of the pancreas is a small extension of the pancreas that hooks around the superior mesenteric artery and vein. Its anatomical relations include:
  • ➤ Superiorly:
  • ➤ Superiorly:
  • ➤ Neck of the pancreas
  • ➤ Neck of the pancreas
  • ➤ Inferiorly:
  • ➤ Inferiorly:
  • ➤ Superior mesenteric vein Superior mesenteric artery
  • ➤ Superior mesenteric vein
  • ➤ Superior mesenteric artery
  • ➤ Anteriorly:
  • ➤ Anteriorly:
  • ➤ Third part of the duodenum Root of the small bowel mesentery
  • ➤ Third part of the duodenum
  • ➤ Root of the small bowel mesentery
  • ➤ Posteriorly:
  • ➤ Posteriorly:
  • ➤ Inferior vena cava Aorta Left renal vein Left psoas muscle Transverse mesocolon
  • ➤ Inferior vena cava
  • ➤ Aorta
  • ➤ Left renal vein
  • ➤ Left psoas muscle
  • ➤ Transverse mesocolon
  • ➤ Medially:
  • ➤ Medially:
  • ➤ Pancreatic duct Common bile duct
  • ➤ Pancreatic duct
  • ➤ Common bile duct
  • ➤ Laterally:
  • ➤ Laterally:
  • ➤ Right renal vessels Right psoas muscle
  • ➤ Right renal vessels
  • ➤ Right psoas muscle
  • ➤ The uncinate process is an important landmark for the surgeon during pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple procedure) as it is often involved in the dissection of the superior mesenteric vein and artery.Top of Form

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient had a tooth extraction three days back. He now presents with a mass in the submandibular region which is otherwise asymptomatic. There is no ulcer on the oral mucosa. On drainage of the discharge, it was foul-smelling with a lot of yellow granules. They showed gram-positive filamentous rods on grams staining. What is the most likely implicated pathogen? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Actinomycetes israelli

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cervicofacial actinomycosis, commonly caused by Actinomyces israelii, presents with submandibular masses, often after dental procedures, with foul-smelling discharge containing yellow sulfur granules. Gram staining reveals gram-positive filamentous rods, confirming the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 1-day-old neonate has not passed urine since birth. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Continue breastfeeding and observe

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ It is normal for a neonate to not pass urine within the first 24 hours; continue breastfeeding and observe the baby.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presented with complaints of paranasal sinus pain and bloody nasal discharge for the past few days. He also has a previous history of hemoptysis and hematuria. Imaging revealed multiple, bilateral, nodular cavitary infiltrates. Which of the following antibodies would be positive in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) c-ANCA

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's presentation suggests granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis . GPA triad typically involves:
  • • granulomatosis with polyangiitis
  • • Wegener's granulomatosis
  • • ENT involvement: Sinus pain and bloody nasal discharge (sinusitis). Pulmonary involvement: Hemoptysis and cavitating nodules on imaging. Renal involvement: Hematuria and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.
  • • ENT involvement: Sinus pain and bloody nasal discharge (sinusitis).
  • • ENT involvement:
  • • Pulmonary involvement: Hemoptysis and cavitating nodules on imaging.
  • • Pulmonary involvement:
  • • Renal involvement: Hematuria and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.
  • • Renal involvement:
  • • The characteristic antibody associated with GPA is c-ANCA (cytoplasmic anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies), which targets proteinase 3.
  • • c-ANCA
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. ANA (Antinuclear Antibodies): Typically associated with systemic lupus erythematosus and other autoimmune diseases.
  • • Option B. ANA (Antinuclear Antibodies):
  • • Option C. Anti-histone antibodies: Associated with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.
  • • Option C. Anti-histone antibodies:
  • • Option D. Anti-Jo 1 antibodies: Associated with polymyositis and dermatomyositis.
  • • Option D. Anti-Jo 1 antibodies:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) is associated with c-ANCA (anti-proteinase 3 antibodies), presenting with ENT, pulmonary, and renal involvement.

questions.text: Laryngismus stridulus is due to which of the following vitamin deficiencies? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngismus stridulus (laryngospasm) can be caused by hypocalcemia, which is often a result of Vitamin D deficiency.

questions.text: Which cell is involved in type 4/delayed type hypersensitivity? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cytotoxic T cell

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A multiparous woman from a low socio-economic status whose husband is a truck driver is to be screened for cervical cancer. What is the best way? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pap smear

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cervical cancer screening is crucial for early detection and prevention. The Pap smear (Papanicolaou test) is the standard screening test for cervical cancer, particularly in resource-limited settings. It involves collecting cells from the cervix to detect precancerous or cancerous changes.
  • • Why Pap Smear?
  • • Accessibility: It is widely available and can be performed in low-resource settings. Cost-effective: It is a cost-effective method for cervical cancer screening. Proven efficacy: It has been proven to significantly reduce the incidence and mortality of cervical cancer through early detection and treatment of precancerous lesions.
  • • Accessibility: It is widely available and can be performed in low-resource settings.
  • • Cost-effective: It is a cost-effective method for cervical cancer screening.
  • • Proven efficacy: It has been proven to significantly reduce the incidence and mortality of cervical cancer through early detection and treatment of precancerous lesions.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. CA125 : This is a biomarker used in the screening and monitoring of ovarian cancer, not cervical cancer.
  • • Option A. CA125
  • • Option B. Laparoscopy : This is a surgical procedure used for diagnosis and treatment but not for routine screening.
  • • Option B. Laparoscopy
  • • Option C. TVS (Transvaginal Sonography): Primarily used for evaluating the uterus and ovaries, not suitable for cervical cancer screening.
  • • Option C. TVS (Transvaginal Sonography):
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The Pap smear is the best and most widely recommended screening test for cervical cancer, especially in low socio-economic and resource-limited settings.

questions.text: A woman presenting with symptoms of urinary tract infection was prescribed a drug that causes tendon rupture and arthropathy. What is the mechanism of action of the drug? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) DNA gyrase inhibition

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fluoroquinolones, which inhibit DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, are associated with serious side effects such as tendon rupture and arthropathy.

questions.text: 50-year-old obese female presents to the emergency department with severe right upper quadrant pain, fever, and nausea. The physician suspects acute cholecystitis and orders imaging studies to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following statements is not true about acute cholecystitis? (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Gall bladder thickness >3 mm on USG

options.label: D
options.text: Preferential visualization of gall bladder in HIDA scan

questions.correct_answer: D. Preferential visualization of gall bladder in HIDA scan
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Preferential visualization of gall bladder in HIDA scan.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute cholecystitis is a common condition characterized by inflammation of the gallbladder, typically due to the presence of gallstones obstructing the cystic duct. Clinical features of acute cholecystitis include right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis. A positive Murphy's sign is right upper quadrant tenderness on palpation. On ultrasound imaging, gall bladder thickness >3 mm is a common finding in acute cholecystitis. The HIDA scan is a diagnostic tool for acute cholecystitis, showing non-visualization of the gall bladder 3 hours after radioisotope administration. Preferential visualization of the gall bladder on a HIDA scan is not a feature of acute cholecystitis. It is important to diagnose and treat acute cholecystitis promptly to prevent complications such as gallbladder perforation or gangrene.

questions.text: The following are correct regarding normal placenta, except: (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Placenta weight at term is 470 g

options.label: C
options.text: Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present

questions.correct_answer: C. Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The statement in option C is incorrect regarding the normal placenta.
  • • Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present: In a normal placenta, the umbilical cord typically contains three vessels (two arteries and one vein), not two. The presence of extraplacental membranes (membranes extending beyond the placental margins) is not a feature of a normal placenta; it is rather an abnormal finding if present.
  • • Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Placenta weight at term is 470 g: This is correct. The average weight of a term placenta is around 500 grams, but it can range from approximately 450 to 700 grams. The option provides a reasonable estimate.
  • • Option A. Placenta weight at term is 470 g:
  • • Option B. Round-oval with 22 cm diameter: This is partially correct. The normal placenta is indeed round to oval, but the average diameter is about 15-20 cm, not 22 cm. The provided diameter exceeds the typical range.
  • • Option B. Round-oval with 22 cm diameter:
  • • Option D. Central thickness > 2.5 cm: This is correct. The normal thickness of the placenta at term is greater than 2.5 cm, commonly around 2.5 to 4 cm. A thickness greater than 2.5 cm falls within the normal range.
  • • Option D. Central thickness > 2.5 cm:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The normal placenta at term typically weighs around 500 grams, has a diameter of 15-20 cm, is 2.5 cm thick, and has a 3-vessel umbilical cord with a central insertion.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 245 Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 245 Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A young man came to the medical OPD with complaints of early morning backache and stiffness, which improves on exercise, and persistent red eyes. On examination, lung expansion was less than 3 cm. X-ray is shown in the image given below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ankylosing spondylitis should be suspected in young patients with inflammatory back pain that improves with exercise, reduced lung expansion, and extra-articular manifestations such as uveitis. The "bamboo spine" on X-ray is a characteristic finding in advanced cases of AS.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child came to the casualty with difficulty in walking and pain in the perianal region. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, yellow needle-shaped crystals are seen under the microscope. What is the test done? ( NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Barberio’s Test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Microchemical tests for Semen: Florence and Barberio test (Both are presumptive tests)
  • ➤ Microchemical tests for Semen:
  • ➤ Microchemical tests for Blood: Teichmann’s and Takayama test (Both are confirmatory tests)
  • ➤ Microchemical tests for Blood:
  • ➤ Non-cellular Semen Markers: Acid phosphatase test (quantitative), Prostate specific antigen or PSA (p30)
  • ➤ Non-cellular Semen Markers:

questions.text: Identify the vitamin deficiency: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vitamin D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin D
  • ➤ Vitamin D

questions.text: The most radiosensitive phase of the cell cycle is: (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) G2 phase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most radiosensitive phase of the cell cycle is the G2-> M (G2>M) phase . During this phase cells are particularly vulnerable to radiation because any damage caused during this phase can lead to immediate catastrophic errors in cell division, leading to cell death.
  • ➤ G2-> M (G2>M) phase

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presented with developmental delay, recurrent chest infections and worsening bony pain. His serum PTH was normal. Calcium was normal and phosphate was low. There is no response to Vitamin D. The probable diagnosis is:(NEET PG 2021)

options.label: C
options.text: Vitamin D dependent rickets type I

options.label: D
options.text: Vitamin D dependent rickets type II

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets is a genetic disorder that results in low phosphate levels and can present with bony pain, developmental delay, and recurrent infections. It is distinct from other forms of rickets due to its genetic basis and the characteristic low phosphate levels in the absence of Vitamin D response.
  • ➤ Ref - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK562285/
  • ➤ Ref - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK562285/
